Workflow

Andreas Bender

2017-07-29

library(magrittr)
library(tidyr)
library(purrr)
library(dplyr)
library(coalitions)

In this vignette we demonstrate the basic workflow using the most recent emnid survey.

Overview

This package calculates coalition probabilities in multi-party systems. To this end we provide some convenience functions, the most important of which are listed below:

  • scrape_wahlrecht: A wrapper function that download the most current survey results from http://www.wahlrecht.de/
  • collapse_parties: Transforms information on percentages received by individual parties in long format and stores them inside a nested tibble (see tidyr::nest)
  • draw_from_posterior: Draws nsim samples from the posterior distribution (i.e. nsim simulated election results based on provided survey)
  • get_seats: Obtain seat distributions for each simulation (see also ?sls)
  • have_majority: Given a list of coalitions of interest, caclulates if the respective coalition would have enough seats for a majority
  • calculate_probs: Given majority tables obtained from have_majority, calculates the probabilities for the respective coalitions to have enough seats for a majority

Read in data

# one line per survey (party information in wide format)
emnid <- scrape_wahlrecht() %>% slice(1:6) 
emnid %>% select(-start, -end)
## # A tibble: 6 x 9
##        datum   cdu   spd gruene   fdp linke   afd sonstige befragte
##       <date> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
## 1 2017-07-22    38    25      8     8     9     8        4     2349
## 2 2017-07-15    38    25      8     7     9     8        5     1263
## 3 2017-07-08    38    25      8     8     9     7        5     1878
## 4 2017-07-01    39    24      8     8     9     7        5      936
## 5 2017-06-24    39    24      8     7     9     8        5     1363
## 6 2017-06-17    39    25      7     7     9     8        5     2054

Collapse survey data

After applying collapse_parties we still have one row per survey, but information on parties and percentage of votes they received is stored in a long format in a separate column (see ?tidyr::nest):

elong <- collapse_parties(emnid)
head(elong)
## # A tibble: 6 x 5
##        datum      start        end befragte           survey
##       <date>     <date>     <date>    <dbl>           <list>
## 1 2017-07-22 2017-07-13 2017-07-19     2349 <tibble [7 x 3]>
## 2 2017-07-15 2017-07-06 2017-07-12     1263 <tibble [7 x 3]>
## 3 2017-07-08 2017-06-30 2017-07-05     1878 <tibble [7 x 3]>
## 4 2017-07-01 2017-06-22 2017-06-24      936 <tibble [7 x 3]>
## 5 2017-06-24 2017-06-16 2017-06-21     1363 <tibble [7 x 3]>
## 6 2017-06-17 2017-06-08 2017-06-13     2054 <tibble [7 x 3]>
elong %>% slice(1) %>% select(survey) %>% unnest()
## # A tibble: 7 x 3
##      party percent  votes
##      <chr>   <dbl>  <dbl>
## 1      cdu      38 892.62
## 2      spd      25 587.25
## 3   gruene       8 187.92
## 4      fdp       8 187.92
## 5    linke       9 211.41
## 6      afd       8 187.92
## 7 sonstige       4  93.96

Simulate elections

Based on each survey we can now simulate nsim elections by drawing from the Dirichlet distribution

elong %<>% mutate(draws = map(survey, draw_from_posterior, nsim=10, correction=0.005))
elong %>% select(datum, survey, draws)
## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##        datum           survey             draws
##       <date>           <list>            <list>
## 1 2017-07-22 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]>
## 2 2017-07-15 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]>
## 3 2017-07-08 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]>
## 4 2017-07-01 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]>
## 5 2017-06-24 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]>
## 6 2017-06-17 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]>
# each row is one election simulation
elong %>% slice(1) %>% select(draws) %>% unnest()
## # A tibble: 10 x 7
##          cdu       spd     gruene        fdp      linke        afd
##        <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
##  1 0.3870682 0.2567568 0.07597416 0.07825459 0.09365761 0.07381995
##  2 0.3759717 0.2395787 0.07995867 0.08308244 0.09373454 0.08398714
##  3 0.3841416 0.2461408 0.07718359 0.07643676 0.09292067 0.08219435
##  4 0.3819951 0.2602311 0.07161976 0.08355520 0.08725304 0.07500094
##  5 0.3927594 0.2457144 0.08038016 0.06993430 0.08702272 0.08995673
##  6 0.3816497 0.2392843 0.07601550 0.08526905 0.08447706 0.08829018
##  7 0.3605600 0.2676467 0.07483379 0.07721017 0.09394500 0.08083374
##  8 0.3785704 0.2475755 0.08372710 0.08965190 0.08651773 0.07584163
##  9 0.3882934 0.2500581 0.07539320 0.08262593 0.09158054 0.07846694
## 10 0.3820102 0.2455825 0.07659540 0.07652390 0.09104097 0.08075518
## # ... with 1 more variables: sonstige <dbl>

Calculate seat distribution

Given the simulated elections, we can calculate the number of seats each party obtained. To do so wee need to have a function that knows how to redistribute seats for the particular election. In Germany for example, seats are distributed according to the system of Sainte-Lague-Scheppers, which is implemented in ?sls.

This makes this package easily extensible to other multi-party systems, as you only need to provide a function that redistributes seats based on percentages obtained by the various parties and provide that function to the distrib.fun argument of the get_seats function:

elong %<>% mutate(seats = map2(draws, survey, get_seats, distrib.fun=sls))
elong %>% select(datum, survey, draws, seats)
## # A tibble: 6 x 4
##        datum           survey             draws             seats
##       <date>           <list>            <list>            <list>
## 1 2017-07-22 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]>
## 2 2017-07-15 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]>
## 3 2017-07-08 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]>
## 4 2017-07-01 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]>
## 5 2017-06-24 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]>
## 6 2017-06-17 <tibble [7 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]>
## sim column indicates simulated elections (rows in draws column)
elong %>% slice(1) %>% select(seats) %>% unnest()
## # A tibble: 60 x 3
##      sim  party seats
##    <int>  <chr> <int>
##  1     1    cdu   240
##  2     1    spd   159
##  3     1 gruene    47
##  4     1    fdp    48
##  5     1  linke    58
##  6     1    afd    46
##  7     2    cdu   235
##  8     2    spd   150
##  9     2 gruene    50
## 10     2    fdp    52
## # ... with 50 more rows

In the above example, given the latest survey, CDU/CSU would have 225 seats in the first simulation, 223 seats in the second simulation, etc.

Calculate majorities

The next step is to define coalitions of interest, then calculate in what percentage of the simulations the coalition would obtain enough seats for a majority.

Below, each list element defines one coalition of interest (one party could potentially obtain absolute majority on their own):

coalitions <- list(
    c("cdu"), 
    c("cdu", "fdp"), 
    c("cdu", "gruene"),
    c("cdu", "fdp", "gruene"), 
    c("spd"), 
    c("spd", "linke"), 
    c("spd", "gruene"),
    c("spd", "linke", "gruene"))


elong %<>% mutate(majorities = map(seats, have_majority, coalitions=coalitions))
elong %>% select(datum, draws, seats, majorities)
## # A tibble: 6 x 4
##        datum             draws             seats        majorities
##       <date>            <list>            <list>            <list>
## 1 2017-07-22 <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 8]>
## 2 2017-07-15 <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 8]>
## 3 2017-07-08 <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 8]>
## 4 2017-07-01 <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 8]>
## 5 2017-06-24 <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 8]>
## 6 2017-06-17 <tibble [10 x 7]> <tibble [60 x 3]> <tibble [10 x 8]>
# The majorities table for each date will have 1 row per simulation
# and one column per coalition
elong %>% slice(1) %>% select(majorities) %>% unnest()
## # A tibble: 10 x 8
##      cdu cdu_fdp cdu_gruene cdu_fdp_gruene   spd linke_spd gruene_spd
##    <lgl>   <lgl>      <lgl>          <lgl> <lgl>     <lgl>      <lgl>
##  1 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  2 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  3 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  4 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  5 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  6 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  7 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  8 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
##  9 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
## 10 FALSE   FALSE      FALSE           TRUE FALSE     FALSE      FALSE
## # ... with 1 more variables: gruene_linke_spd <lgl>

Calculate coalition probabilities

The last step is to calculate the coalition probabilities (note that by default we exclude “superior” coalitions, i.e. if “cdu/csu” have a majority on their own, this simulation will not be counted to the simulation with majority for “cdu/csu” and “fdp”, see example in ?calculate_probs):

elong %<>% mutate(probabilities = map(majorities, calculate_probs, 
    coalitions=coalitions))
elong %>% select(datum, majorities, probabilities)
## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##        datum        majorities    probabilities
##       <date>            <list>           <list>
## 1 2017-07-22 <tibble [10 x 8]> <tibble [8 x 2]>
## 2 2017-07-15 <tibble [10 x 8]> <tibble [8 x 2]>
## 3 2017-07-08 <tibble [10 x 8]> <tibble [8 x 2]>
## 4 2017-07-01 <tibble [10 x 8]> <tibble [8 x 2]>
## 5 2017-06-24 <tibble [10 x 8]> <tibble [8 x 2]>
## 6 2017-06-17 <tibble [10 x 8]> <tibble [8 x 2]>
# one row per coalition
elong %>% slice(1) %>% select(probabilities) %>% unnest()
## # A tibble: 8 x 2
##          coalition probability
##              <chr>       <dbl>
## 1              cdu           0
## 2          cdu_fdp           0
## 3       cdu_gruene           0
## 4   cdu_fdp_gruene         100
## 5              spd           0
## 6        linke_spd           0
## 7       gruene_spd           0
## 8 gruene_linke_spd           0

Wrapper

There is a wrapper function that directly returns probabilities:

elong <- collapse_parties(emnid)
elong %>% get_probabilities(nsim=10) %>% unnest()
## # A tibble: 36 x 2
##           coalition probability
##               <chr>       <dbl>
##  1              cdu           0
##  2          cdu_fdp           0
##  3   cdu_fdp_gruene         100
##  4              spd           0
##  5        linke_spd           0
##  6 gruene_linke_spd           0
##  7              cdu           0
##  8          cdu_fdp           0
##  9   cdu_fdp_gruene         100
## 10              spd           0
## # ... with 26 more rows
